entry.title: Git
entry.content:
From my previous experience, I have been always encountering 2 difficult things when writing a program. One is to name a variable appropariately, the other is version control. This blog mainly focusing on solving the later problem.

Due to the complexity of real problem and human nature, we don’t always know what we want clearly. It’s often that we go back and forth, modify the code and modify it back. It’s hard and tedious to keep track and organize, which will eventually hurt our efficiency. Luckily, we can use Git to help us.

Git Cheetsheet

Intro to Git

Git is a distributed version control system developed by Linus (the guy who also initiated Linux). The workflow of git shows as below. images are adopted from git -the simple guide

Repository

Create

  1. mkdir folder
  2. cd into the folder
  3. git init

you can use ls .ah to check, there should be a .git folder created, believe me, you don’t really want to modify it.

Add file

submit was divided into two steps, first add then commit

  1. tell Git that you want to add file to repository, this will add the modified file in workplace to stage ( you may image it as a cache)

  2. tell Git that you want to submit, this add the stage file to repository

    git clone /path/to/repository

    git clone username@host:/path/to/repository

git reset –hard HEAD^

git reset –hard commit_id

git clone git@github.com:username/repository_name.git

git checkout -b branch_name
git add file_name
git commit -m “add merge”
git checkout master
git merge –no-ff -m “merge with no-ff” branch_name

Windows:

Thumbs.db
ehthumbs.db
Desktop.ini

Python:

.py[cod].so
.egg.egg-info
dist
build

My configurations:

db.ini
deploy_key_rsa
`
then submit .gitignore to repository,

git ignore templates

note: 使用Windows的童鞋注意了，如果你在资源管理器里新建一个.gitignore文件，它会非常弱智地提示你必须输入文件名，但是在文本编辑器里“保存”或者“另存为”就可以把文件保存为.gitignore了。

some times you really want to add some file to repository but it was ignored by .gitignore, you may use -f to add forcable
eg:
git add -f App.class

Check .ignore file

use git check-ignore
eg:
git check-ignore -v App.class

to see what kind of rules to ignore the file.

More

build your own Git

entry.title: Markdown extensions
entry.content:
Markdown focus on writing, the simplicity and conciseness of Markdown syntax make it easy to write some ordinary documantation. However, sometimes you may need some features or something cooler where the basic syntax of markdown may not be enough. Luckily, you can write HTML in a markdown file.

contents are extracted from ref1

…why I think HTML code is kind of ugly

1. Breif intro to HTML

HTML ( HyperText Markup Language, a.k.a “How To Meet Ladies” a geek joke from Silicion Valley ) is a standard markup language used to create web pages. Compare to coding language, HTML is a set of markup tags used to describe a webpage. A typical HTML file usually ends up with .html or .htm which can be viewed by a browser. For example:

  • <!DOCTYPE html>: claims as HTML5 document, “html” is case-incensitive.
  • <html>: root, defines the whole HTML document.
  • <head>: contains meta data as <meta charset="utf-8"> and define the coding format as utf-8, sometimes you run into a messy code, check the coding format. For more info, please refer to ref2
  • <title>: contains the title of the document
  • <body>: defines the main content
  • <h1>: defines a heading
  • <p>: defines a paragraph

The architecture of HTML can be described as
PS: only the body part will be displayed in webpages.

2. Tags in HTML

The tags is formatted as <keyword>, eg <html>, and should be paired, eg <b> and </b>, which is called the opening tag and close tag respectively. Though Tags is case-insensitive, but lower case is usually preferred.

2.1 Heading and paragraph

2.1.1 Heading

use <h1> - <h6>, use heading only if you want to set a heading, not for the bold or size purpose. eg:

<h1>This is a heading</h1>

2.1.2 Paragraph

use <p> to start a new paragraph, if you want to start a new line without starting a new paragraph, you can use <br>, eg:

<p>This is a paragraph</p> \
<p>This is <br> a <br> paragraph</p>

2.1.3 Others

use <hr> to set horizontal line in contents.

use <!-- --> to add comments, which is ignored by the browswer and not shown

<!-- This is a comment -->

when displaying, browser will automatically remove extra space and lines in HTML files

empty elements contains no content, it was closed by / in the opeing tag, like the image above, also <br /> as a break.

2.2 List

  • ordered list : <ol>
  • unordered list: <ul>
  • self-define list: <dl> # for more info
  • item of list: <li>

an example of nested list


  • Coffee

  • Tea

    • Black tea

    • Green tea

      • China

      • Africa





  • Milk

2.3 Links

use <a>, href is link address , set target="_blank" to open the link in a new Tab, eg:

<a href="http://www.vinkwok.github.io" target="_blank">This is my blog link</a>

use id to create a bookmark within the HTML page, eg:

<a id="tips">Tips</a> \
<a href="#tips">Go to tips in the same page</a> \
<a href="http://www.runoob.com/html/html-links.html#tips"> Go to tips from the other page</a>

2.4 Tables

use <table> to define a table, use <tr> to define a row, <td> to define a cell (‘td’ means ‘table data’), <th> to define the header. Example:














Header 1 Header 2
row 1, cell 1 row 1, cell 2
row 2, cell 1 row 2, cell 2

for more information about boarder, title, cell spanning, cell spacing, refer to blog

2.5 Images

<img> is an empty tag, name and size is defined by the attribute. eg:

<img src="/images/logo.png" alt="logo" width="258" height="39" />
use src to show the pic, use alt to replace the image with text when image cannot be displayed, use height and width to denote the length and width of the image (usually a good habit to do so)

2.6 CSS style

Using CSS (Cascading Style Sheets) to “Rendering”. How to add CSS to HTML?

  1. Include style in <>

    I am so handsome

2.7 Framework

2.8 Colors

3. Elements’ attributes

The addditional information of elements, the attributes is usually contained in opening tag, consists of name/value pair, eg:
<a href="http://www.vinkwok.github.io">This is a link</a>

for more attributes, refer to ref3

4. Text formatting

4.1 Bold and italic

<b>bold</b> <italic>italic</italic> \
<strong>strong</strong> <em>em</em>

bold italic \
strong em

here the former and the latter is the same, but the latter usually means you want to empahsize.

4.2 Size

<big>big</big> <small>small</small>

big small

4.3 Delete and insert

<del>blue</del> <ins>red</ins>

blue red

4.4 Sub and sup script

C<sub>2<sup>n</sup></sub>
C2n

how to set the sub and sup for the same element

4.5 Control space and line using pre

pre        tagcontrol    space and lines

other format please look into the example of ref4

entry.title: Summary of Type-I/II error and confusion matrix
entry.content:
When we make decisions, there is no gurantee that we are always right. (actually I usually make bad choice, especially when dealing with exams). There are two types of “wrong”, sometimes we misjudge the True to be False (false positive, Type I error), while sometimes we misjudge the False to be True (false nagative, Type II error). It’s a little confusing just playing with the words, so here I make an summary on type-I/II error and the confusion matrix.

In hypothesis testing

We define $H_0$ as the null hypothesis, and :

  • Type-I error: reject $H_0$ though it’s true
  • Type-II error: not reject $H_0$ though it’s not true

for all scenarios:

  ActualSituation
  $H_0$ is true$H_0$ is NOT true
StatisticalDo NOT reject $H_0$correct decision 1-$\alpha$Type-II error $\beta$
DecisionReject $H_0$Type-I error $\alpha$correct decision (power) 1-$\beta$

Note: power is to reject null hypothesis when it’s not true

In machine learning

While for a binarized classification question (to judge whether it’s true or false), there is not always a consistency between prediciton and actual situation, where we have a confusion matrix:

  ActualSituation
  TrueFalse
PredictedTruetrue positive (TP)false positive (FP)
ConditionFalsefalse negative (FN)true negative (TN)

There are some parameters you may often come across

ParametersFormulaInterpretation
sensitivity, recall, or true positive rate (TPR)$\frac{TP}{TP+FN}$ability to detect True
specificity, selectivity or true negative rate (TNR)$\frac{TN}{TN+FP}$ability to detect False
false discovery rate (FDR)$\frac{FP}{TP+FP}$misfound true
precision$\frac{TP}{TP+FP}$ratio of true positive in predicted positive
Accuracy$\frac{TP+TN}{TP+TN+FP+FN}$correct prediction in all prediction.

And the matthews correlation coefficient(MCC) is:

$$ MCC = \frac{TP \times TN - FP \times FN}{\sqrt{(TP+FP)(TP+FN)(TN+FP)(TN+FN)}} $$

Note the difference between the sensitivity and precision, the former is how many positive you can detect in all positive, the latter is among all positive you predicted, how many is true. In my opinion, sensitivity is the ability to discover, while precision is the ability to control the discovery unique. (specificity). In real world, we can not always achieve good in both sensitivity and precision.

Now it’s intriguing to think, given a method, what will determine the sensitivity and precision? I would say, the threshold. In fact, any statistical decision is made based on a threshold (like p-value < 0.05). It’s the same here, different thresholds give different sensitivity and precision.

If the threshold is too low, a lot of cases will be intepreted as positive, the sensitivity is high but the specificity will be low. On the other hand if threshold is too high, a lot of positive cases wil be missed, the sensitivity is low but the specificity will be high. So how do we determine the threshold to achieve the best combination between sensitivity and presion?

We can trace the changes of sensitivity and specificity as the threshold changes. If we plot the sensitivity over 1-specificity (plot true positive rate (TPR) against the false positive rate), we can get the Receiver Operating Characteristic curve (ROC).

Similarities between these 2 topics

one more thing related to the precsion. But it’s about the numerical precision. Just think of that 1/3 is a finite decimal fraction when using the base of 3, which means that whether a decimal is a repeating decimal depends on the base it use.

Considering More

One interesting topic is considering asymmetry of these 2 type errors. For example, sometimes the type-I and type-II error are not of equal importance. Especially in disease diagnosis, usually The cost of misjudging a heathy person is tolerable, but the cost of misjudging a disease person is usually high (may cost a life…). So it’s very important for threshold choosing to control the type-I and type-II error, Luckily we can use Neyman-Person Criterion to address such probelm. For more information, please refer to this paper

entry.title: Markdown math
entry.content:
Writing math formula with markdown KATEX. This blog also contains some knowledge writing $\TeX{}$, which can help you to write math formula with markdown easily.

Begin with

use single dollar to show the math formula within the row

$e^{i*\pi} +1 = 0$ is a beautiful equation

use double dollar to show the formula in next row

if a is the hypotenuse length of a right triangle with right angle length b and c, then

$$a^2 = \sqrt{b^2 + c^2}$$

For more symbols, please refer to Symbols and Functions, Function support in KATEX

Math in LaTeX

Symbols

SymbolsCode
$\alpha, eta$\alpha, eta
$\lambda$\lambda
$\pi$\pi
$ heta$ heta
$\mu$\mu
$\delta$\delta
$\Phi$\Phi
$\xi$\xi
$\gamma$\gamma
$\Gamma$\Gamma

To get the upper class of the symbol, just capitalize the initial character of that symbol. like $ heta, \Theta$ corresponds to $ heta, \Theta$

some symbols are reserved for $\LaTeX$, like % & _ { } # ^ ~, use \ to show them in the docs. To add space in formula, use \quad or \qquad.
For more symbols, please refer to ref1 ref2 ref3

Oprator and calculus

Arithmetic operator

Basic operator

Operatorcode
$+$+
$-$-
$ imes$ imes
$\div$\div
$\pm$\pm

Relation operators

OperatorCodeOperatorCode
$\lt$\lt$\gt$\gt
$\le$\le$\ge$\ge
$\ll$\ll$\gg$\gg
$=$=$\approx$\approx
$ eq$ eq$\propto$\propto
$ ot$ ot
$ ot>$ ot>

Big operators

Operatorcode
$\sum$\sum
$\prod$\prod

Logical operator

Sets operator

OperatorcodeOperatorcode
$\in$\in$\subset$\subset
$ i$ i$\supset$\supset
$ otin$ otin$ ot\subset$ ot\subset
$\cup$\cup$\subseteq$\subseteq
$\cap$\cap$\supseteq$\supseteq

proposition operator

OperatorcodeOperatorcode
$ ecause$ ecause$\Leftarrow$\Leftarrow
$ herefore$ herefore$\Rightarrow$\Rightarrow
$\land$\land$\Leftrightarrow$\Leftrightarrow
$\lor$\lor$ orall$ orall
$\lnot$\lnot$\exists$\exists

Big operators

Operatorcode
$ igcup$ igcup
$ igcap$ igcap

Caculus

Deriviation

SymbolsCode
$y\prime$y\prime
$\lim$\lim
$ o$ o
$\infty$\infty
$\partial$\partial
$ abla$ abla

Integral

SymbolsCode
$\int$\int
$\iint$\iint
$\iiint$\iiint
$\oint$\oint

Note: the sum, product, integral’s upper and lower limit are specified with ^ and _
for more information, please refer to this blog

Super-sub scripts and tags

use ^ and _ to show superscripts and subscripts respectively, if you want to include more than one characters, use {...} to group them. Also you can use ag{...} at the begining to add tags of the formula

$$ ag{this is a tag}f(x) = \int^{+\infty}_{-\infty}e^{-x}dx $$

Square root

The square root is entered as \sqrt; the $n^{th}$ root is generated with \sqrt[n]. If just the sign is needed, use \surd.

$$\sqrt[3]{2} $$

Fraction

rac{...}{...}, This style is obtainable
in text style with frac. The reverse, i.e. display style fraction in text is made with \dfrac.

the pdf of normal distribution N~($\mu$,$\delta$):

$$f(x) = rac{1}{\sqrt{2\pi}\delta}e^{- rac{(x-\mu)^2}{\delta^2}}$$

Dots type

dotscode
$\cdot$\cdot
$\ldots$\ldots
$\vdots$\vdots
$\ddots$\ddots

Under-over line/braces

The commands \overline and \underline create horizontal lines directly over or under an expression

$$0.\overline{3} = \underline{\underline{1/3}}$$

The commands \overbrace and \underbrace create long horizontal braces over or under an expression

$$\underbrace{\overbrace{(a+b+c)}^6 \cdot \overbrace{(d+e+f)}^7}_ ext{meaning of life} = 42$$

Hat and tilde

$$f(x) = x^2 \qquad f’(x) = 2x \qquad f’’(x) = 2 $$

$$ \hat{XY} \quad \widehat{XY} \quad ar{x_0} \quad ar{x}_0$$

Wide hats and tildes covering several characters are generated with \widetilde and \widehat. Notice the difference between \hat and \widehat and the
placement of ar for a variable with subscript

Delimiters

Regular ones

Round and square brackets can be entered with the
corresponding keys and curly braces with \{, all other delimiters are generated with special commands (e.g. \updownarrow).

If you put \left in front of an opening delimiter and ight in front of a closing delimiter, LATEX will automatically determine the correct size of the delimiter.

$$1 + \left( rac{1}{1-x^{2}} ight)^3 \qquad \left. \ddagger rac{~}{~} ight) $$

Large ones

using the commands ig, \Big, igg and \Bigg as prefixes to most delimiter commands

$$\Big((x+1)(x-1)\Big)^{2} $$

$$ ig( \Big( igg( \Bigg( $$

$$ ig| \Big| igg| \Bigg| $$

$$ ig\Downarrow \Big\Downarrow igg\Downarrow \Bigg\Downarrow $$

Stack symbols

$$f_n(x) \stackrel{*}{\approx} 1$$
$$\sum^n_{\stackrel{0<i<n}{j\subseteq i}}$$

Bold Symbols

use \mathbf, mathematical symbols are normally italic, and doesn’t work on lower case Greek letters

$\mathbf{\mu}$, $\mathbf{M}$

use pmb or bm. (bm does not work on the hexo blog)

$\pmb{\mu}$, $\pmb{A}$, $ oldsymbol{I}$

Such method can also be used to make letters bold

Vectors

This is done with the \vec command. The two commands
\overrightarrow and \overleftarrow are useful to denote the vector

$$ \vec{a} \qquad \vec{AB} \qquad \overrightarrow{AB} $$

Arrays and Matrices

Arrays

use the array environment, with \\ command to break lines.

$$
egin{array}{}
x_1 & x_2 & \ldots \
x_3 & x_4 & \ldots \
\vdots & \vdots & \ddots
\end{array}
$$

the {} behind {array} denotes the format of elements, you can add r,c,l(right center left) and other format you like, for example, the code below shows the first and the second element are centered and separate with the third element with | which is also centered

$$
\left[
egin{array}{cc|c}
1 & 2 & 3 \
4 & 5 & 6
\end{array}
ight]
$$

Matrix

use & to separate elements in one row, and \\ to separate rows

simple matrix

$$
egin{matrix}
a & b \
c & d
\end{matrix}
$$

matrix with delimiter

change the parameter in egin{...}, \end{...}. If we note the matrix form with parameter matrix as A then other parameters can be shown like this:

parametersymbol
matrixA
pmatrix(A)
bmatrix[A]
Bmatrix{A}
vmatrixdet(A)
Vmatrixnorm(A)

examples:

$$
egin{bmatrix}
1 & 2 & 3 \
4 & 5 & 6 \
7 & 8 & 9
\end{bmatrix}
$$

matrix with ellipsis

$$
\left[
egin{matrix}
x_{11} & x_{12} & \cdots & x_{1n} \
x_{21} & x_{22} & \cdots & x_{2n} \
\vdots & \vdots & \ddots & \vdots \
x_{n1} & x_{n2} & \cdots & x_{nn} \
\end{matrix}
ight]
$$

Cases and align

Cases

See a case

$$
f(x) = egin{cases}
1 & ext{if } x \in Q \
0 & ext{if } x ot\in Q
\end{cases}
$$

Align

use & to denote the location of align, use \ to change a row.

$$
egin {aligned}
A&=B \
&=C \
&=D
\end {aligned}
$$

Functions

Names of functions are often typeset in an upright font, and not in italics as variables are, $\LaTeX$ provide some of these common function names:

$$ \lim_{x ightarrow 0} rac{\sin x}{x}=1 $$

For functions missing from the list, use the \DeclareMathOperator command. But we cannot do that here as the KATEX cannot support euqation environment right now. There are many things that the current KATEX cannot support. Hope the developers release the new version ASAP.

Distributions

binomial distribution

$$ inom{n}{k} = inom{n-1}{k} + inom{n-1}{k-1}$$

END

a interesting thing is: The version of $\LaTeX$ starts from 3 (instaead of 1), converging to $\pi$, the latest version is 3.141592653

at last, someone must have recognized this :-)

$$
egin{matrix}
m\pmb{L}\ \ \ \ \ m\pmb{\Theta} \
{\ \ \ m\pmb{V}}{inc \ } { m\pmb{E}}{nt} \
\end{matrix}
$$

To Be Continued…

entry.title: Markdown basics
entry.content:
Markdown is suitable for documentation. This blog gives a introduction to basic writing skills in markdown. The contents are extracted from ref1, ref2, ref3, ref4.

Shortcuts

Ctrl+Shift+V : a preview of Markdown code in HTML format. Press again to return to Markdown code
Ctrl+Space : a context sensitive list of Markdown commands that can be used. eg: type “link”, and press Ctrl+Space to insert a hyperlink.

Header

use # to define header, the number of # corresponds to the rank of header

Alternatively, for H1 and H2, an underline-ish style:

Font

use * or _ to show italic font

This text will be italic

use ** or __ to show bold font

This text will be bold

You can also combine them

Strikethrough

Any word wrapped with two tildes

like this, will appear crossed out.

Ordered List

To order your list, precede each line with a number.

  1. Item 1
  2. Item 2
  3. Item 3
    1. Item 3a
    2. Item 3b

Unordered List

use - or *.

  • Item 1
  • Item 2
    • item 2a
    • item 2b
  1. Item a
  2. Item b

Nested Lists

using the web editor on GitHub or a text editor that uses a monospaced font, create a nested list by indenting one or more list items below another item.
note: the list marker character (- or *) lies must be directly below the first character of the text in the item above it.

  1. First list item
    • First nested list item
      • Second nested list item

using non monospaced font? count the number of characters, add the same amount of spaces.
for more infomation, please see GitHub Flavored Markdown Spec.

Blockquotes

quote txt with >

As Kanye West said:

We’re living the future so
the present is our past.

Quoting code

call out code or a command within a sentence with single backticks.

Use git status to list all new or modified files that haven’t yet been committed.

To format code or text into its own distinct block, use triple backticks in the beginning and the end.

Some basic Git commands are:

Links

http://github.com - use address directly, automatic forms the link!
or create an inline link by wrapping link text in brackets [ ], and then wrapping the URL in parentheses ( ), you can also add a tag of the link (the words that appear when the mouse hangs over it), just use " " to embrace the tags after the link, the tag and the link are seperated by .

GitHub

Section links

link directly to a section in a rendered file by hovering over the section heading to expose the link.

header

Relative links

define relative links and image paths to help navigate to other files in your repository,
A relative link is a link that is relative to the current file.

Images

Format:

  • online: url is the address to the img
  • local : url is the path to the img, eg: D:/用户目录/图片/MIT.jpg

Table

dividing them with hyphens - (for the first row), and then separating each column with a pipe |:

First HeaderSecond Header
Content from cell 1Content from cell 2
Content in the first columnContent in the second column

Task Lists

To create a task list, preface list items with [ ]. To mark a task as complete, use [x].

  • this is an incomplete item
  • this is a complete item
  • @mentions, #refs, links, formatting, and tags supported
  • list syntax required (any unordered or ordered list supported)

it doesn’t work locally, why? for more information please see task lists

Ignoring Markdown formatting

using \ before the Markdown character, like:
\*\*look** means **look**
